text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

NARRATOR: When you're
an ex-con, sometimes you

have hidden talents nobody
is really checking for.
(RAPPING) Hey!

Did you get the job at the
shipping warehouse or not?

I got something
better than a job.
I got a gig.
I don't follow.
I've always had a dream.
Me too.

I always had a dream of
owning property in New York.
It's never going to happen.
Never say never.
I'm a probation officer.
I live in Manhattan.

If this was my apartment,
I would be in the bedroom,
and you would be in the kitchen.

Well, I'm not
giving up on my dream
to be in a Broadway musical.
Yeah.
[SNICKERS]
You see, I've been--

I've been performing
on the subway.
You know that's a tough crowd.
And I've really honed my craft.

I got a gig lined up
at a spot in Newark.
That's not even off Broadway.
That's Jersey.
Yeah.

And it's the late
show, 10:00 PM.

That's not gonna
fly, twinkle toes.

Come on, Officer
Rogers, please.

You take that job, I
have to extend your curfew

and give you special permission
to go across the state.
Why would I do that?

Because it's my lifelong dream
to sing and dance in a place

where no one stuffs singles
in your booty crack.

And it's the only thing that
gets me up every morning.
It sounds a little thin.
All right, I'll bite.

Let me see your act.
- What?
Right now?

You want special
permission to push curfew,
you better be sensational.
And I have high standards.

I saw Diddy in "A
Raisin in the Sun."
I can't do it here.

I don't have any of
the production values.
My act don't work in no office.
No ambience.

Oh, but a subway
platform will do.

You come check out my show.
If I don't kill it, then--

Then you'll have yourself
at the shipping warehouse
Monday morning?
Yes, ma'am.
But I ain't worried about that.
My show is fire.

(SINGING) Oh, my life
was going not right.
But now, I'm in the spotlight.
I always knew I would go far.
And that's why I'm a star!
That one's a star!
[APPLAUSE, CHEERING]
[LAUGHS]
Thank you, gentlemen, thank you.
[LAUGHS]
So what'd you think?
I don't know.

I thought you were
a little pitchy.
[SCOFFS]
(RAPPING) Hey!

After 15 years in prison,
I'm even more motivated to get
myself together.

When I do that, that's
when I'm gonna be proud.

If you gonna live
here, you're gonna work.

You need to start
your own restaurant.

Wow, this is a
metaphor for exactly
what you two are all about--

nice and shiny on the outside,
dingy and empty on the inside.

- I'm in charge.
- That's me!
Ha, ha!

Look at you looking
like a black [INAUDIBLE]..
This is important to me.

I want my kids to look
at me with admiration.

A second chance is
a beautiful thing.
(RAPPING) We need work.

Get your hands on
the dashboard now.

A few bad apples
doesn't ruin the bunch.

That's coming
from a white dude.
All cops are not bad.

That's coming
from a black chick
that married the white dude.

And that's coming
from a black ex-crack
dealer who hates the police.
Touche.

That's coming from a person
who has a cousin named Touche.

(SINGING) We're back
in business, baby.

"The Last OG," new season
premieres April 2 on TBS.
